As we enter into the athletic season, there are some new rules in place for attendance. Please be advised of the following protocols:

1. We will be performing temperature checks upon entry - If you are running a fever, you will be denied entry.

2. Masks will be required to enter the building - All entry will be through the NORTH MPAC doors.

3. Masks will need to be worn while inside the building

4. Masks will be required to enter outside events (waiting in line for ticket, etc.) but may be removed if social distancing can be achieved (6 Feet). Please wear a mask when traveling to the restroom and concession stand.

5. If you are not feeling well or are experiencing any COVID 19 symptoms, please remain at home.

Thank you for understanding our safety precautions. GO RAMS!!

Students will NO LONGER be able to pick up their own silverware, milk, or serve themselves on the food line. Condiments will be pre-packaged. The self-serve salad bar will no longer be available. Food service workers will be the primary handler of all food, beverage, and condiments until it is in the hands of each student. This may affect a la carte as well. These procedures will continue until we feel it is safe to resume student self-serve.

School districts throughout Kansas and the Four-State Area continue to deal with flu-like illnesses that are causing students to miss school.

The symptoms of seasonal flu include:

Fever greater than 100 degrees
Body aches
Coughing
Sore throat
Respiratory congestion
In some cases, diarrhea and vomiting

Individuals who experience the above symptoms should contact their physician, who will determine whether testing or treatment is needed.

For more information you can visit Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (cdc.gov/flu) or The Kansas Department of Health and Enviroment (kdheks.gov/flu/index.html).

The CDC has also published The Flu: A Guide for Parents that can be found at https://www.usd404.org/cms/lib/KS01001120/Centricity/Domain/1/Flu%20Guide%20for%20Parents.pdf.

Two RHS students from HOSA Future Health Professionals, the Career and Technical Student Organization for the Health Careers Class, organized and presented a project to educate middle school students on Type I Diabetes.

Riley Tash and Mia Moss presented information regarding the auto-immune disease to nine classes. Covered in the presentation was diagnosis, symptoms, care, and maintenance of blood sugar. Middle school students were allowed to view and discuss diabetic supplies and sites. Some students were brave enough to check their blood sugars by finger stick with a teacher’s assistance.

A very special thanks you to Mrs. Pant and Mr. Fox for allowing the presentations to take place in their classes.
